node.title: British lawyer who was asked to stop farting in office loses harassment case
node.description: A British lawyer who claimed harassment after being asked to stop farting by a colleague has lost his case.
node.content: ["A British lawyer who claimed harassment after being asked to stop farting by a colleague has lost his case.", "Tarique Mohammed was a senior barrister with the Crown Prosecution Service for England and Wales. In 2016 he began sharing an office with Paul McGorry, The Irish Times reported.", "McGorry reportedly took exception to Mohammed's frequent flatulence in the otherwise quiet room, asking him if it was necessary and requesting he step outside.\u00a0", "\"Mr McGorry was aware the claimant had had a heart attack but he was not aware of what medication the claimant was taking or that flatulence was a side effect of the medication,\" a tribunal was told.\u00a0", "An \"embarrassed\" Mohammed refused to step outside, and was soon moved to another team which required him working one day a week in another town more than an hour's drive away. He went on sick leave, and in 2020 had his employment terminated.\u00a0", "He launched a grievance claim, claiming he was harassed and discriminated against due to his flatulence.\u00a0", "The\u00a0 Crown Prosecution Service's tribunal threw out those claims, saying his colleague's request that he step outside \"was not an unreasonable question to ask, when there had been repeated incidents of flatulence in a small office\". It also said many of his complaints \"were caused or aggravated\" by him \"overreacting\".\u00a0", "The Guardian reported he was awarded compensation however because the service wouldn't allow him to work more from home, where he could presumably fart to his heart's content.\u00a0", "\u00a0"]
